title: Parents get 'fright of their life' after electric blanket catches fire as daughter, 7, lay in bed
text:

Two parents were traumatised when an electric blanket caught fire as their seven-year-old girl lay reading in bed. 
Little Bethany Anderson shouted that she could "hear and smell party poppers" when her terrified mum and dad ran in and found "smoke and sparks flying everywhere". 
But the couple, who had the 'fright of their life' are disappointed by the reaction from manufacturer Morphy Richards, who had given them no resolution four months down the line, 
Quick-thinking mum Lynsey Anderson grabbed the seven-year-old and got her to safety while husband Mark stopped the fire from spreading. 
Mark, 35, told the Sunday Mail's The Judge column : “I’m appalled and angry at the way we’re being treated. There was a plume of smoke and sparks flying everywhere. The seven-year-old was under a Morphy Richards blanket 
“And this from a blanket which is advertised as having an overheat system and cut-off switch. 
“If we hadn’t been there, the whole room could have gone up.” 
Mark, an assistant manager with a glazing firm, had switched on the blanket as Bethany lay on his bed with her iPad on November 10. Read More Socks in bed: How Brits are beating energy bills 
He said: “I was out in the hall when Bethany shouted that she could hear and smell party poppers. 
“I didn’t know what she was talking about at first. Then the smell became more intense so I pulled back the duvet and saw electrical sparks. 
“The bed was smouldering and burning and I could hear frazzling noises.” 
Mark, of Larkhall, Lanarkshire, pulled the plug from the wall and managed to extinguish the fire. 
But the bed was ruined as the blanket had burned two holes in the mattress. 
Lynsey, 35, also mum to 18-month-old Harry, contacted Morphy Richards the next day. Read More 
Mark said: “They collected the blanket for inspection and sent us a new one, which was the last thing we wanted.” 
Lynsey then received a letter from Morphy Richards with the results of their inspection. 
Mark said: “It said a power cable connector had burnt through, with the most likely cause a ‘failed solder joint within the connector’.” 
Morphy Richards offered to replace the couple’s mattress, which cost £700. 
But reportedly when no money was forthcoming, Mark complained and they referred him to lawyers. 
Morphy Richards said: “We’re sorry to hear Mr Anderson is unhappy with the service he has received and that he feels we haven’t met our high standards. 
“We take any complaint of this kind seriously and it’s being taken through our internal processes to ensure we can offer the most suitable solution.” Like us on Facebook
